description.narrative: Free Press Unlimited and the European Journalism Centre (EJC) will work within the Strategic Partnership on lobby and advocacy in order to ensure that the information needs as well as research and monitoring efforts of local (media) actors will be highlighted at the relevant international stage to ensure connectivity between local, regional and international discussions. Relevant focus for the international programme are safety of reporters, gender equality and increased understanding for the role of the media in international development efforts. A link to EJC's report on these activities can be found under 'related activities.

Free Press Unlimited, European Journalism Centre and the Ministry will develop advocacy capacity with local partners to end impunity and increase the safety of journalists in relevant multilateral bodies such as UNESCO, the Office of the High Commisioner of Human Rights, the United Nations-General Assembly. -Free Press Unlimited will provide leadership and support to the international network of emergency safety assistance organisations through the Reporters Respond fund and the coordination mechanism of the Journalists in Distress Network. -Free Press Unlimited will coordinate in fragile states with international and local media actors through Global Forum for Media Development to ensure donor coordination – add value and synergy to international efforts to increase freedom of expression and media freedom – strengthen the local actors capacity to cooperate and advocate jointly. -Free Press Unlimited will strengthen the international advocacy for access to information within the sustainable development goals, strengthen implementation of freedom to access information laws and as well as for a free open and secure Internet with the Global Forum for Media Development, the World Wide Web Foundation and Article 19. -Free Press Unlimited will research malware proliferation and provide tool kits for circumvention technologies and conduct training for partners in the target countries. In order for the lobby and advocacy strategy to work, European Journalism Centre believes there is also a strong necessity to develop an international program. On the one hand, lobby and advocacy efforts are immensely effective when and if international (diplomatic and media) pressure is applied to persuade government and authorities to improve and change their behavior and enabling environment. This is especially true in the area of safety. On the other hand, global networks of peer organizations can leverage learning, research and development efforts by other actors. Coordination can also foster collective attention to issues and especially help and improve harmonization of intervention efforts and aid effectiveness.

description.narrative: Provide the Dutch MoFA with information on violations and threats to journalist's safety for the Universal Periodic Review. + Advocate that they take this into account in their overall policy-making. 2017: EJC attended the UN Plan of Action on the Safety of Journalists consultation at Unesco in Geneva on 29 June along with a representative from Project Syndicate's Press Released press freedom global editorial series. The convening provided an open platform for dialogue on press freedom organisations' recommendations to the UN Plan. Takeaways included a growing consensus among many UN member states on the need to support journalist safety and end impunity. Priorities were discussed ranging from inclusion of online harassment of journalists ­especially female­ in the UN Plan to the explosive growth of the journalist prison population: currently the largest ever recorded. The underreported nature - 'awareness'/coverage - in the media itself of press freedom issues provides numerous opportunities for the "Press Released" series to coordinate with press freedom stakeholders on visibility and awareness campaigns at the global level. The consultative mechanism is important because it allows specific press freedom violation cases (e.g. Bolivia, Zimbabwe) that are often overshadowed by major violations (Mexico, Turkey, Venezuala) to receive a wider hearing.

description.narrative: The European Journalism Centre launched “Press Released”, in January 2017, a new platform and commentary series established in partnership with non-profit editorial service Project Syndicate to stimulate debate and heightened awareness around the global challenges confronting media and journalists. The series, available to Project Syndicate’s 500+ member media outlets for publication, showcases material produced by some of the organisation’s most prolific contributors specialised in the media field. The series will also feature commentary by economic, political and cultural thought leaders to illustrate media’s impacts across all spheres of society. “Press Released” addresses the growing threats to independent media and journalist safety across the globe. From ‘fake news’ and digital security to self-censorship and outdated business models, “Press Released” seeks to immerse and engage readers in the latest issues raging around the media and the consequences for civil society and good governance. The first editorial outputs within the reporting period January-March included contributions on issues impacting media by Peter Singer, Francis Fukuyama, Sergei Guriev, Tony Karon, Chris Patten and Aleksander Dardeli. During April-June two columns were published, by Sasahi Tharoor and Steven Rosenbaum. During July-September four columns were published by Hannah Storm, Maria Xynou, Anya Schiffrin and Nina Ognianova. During Oct-Dec 5 columns were published by Jago Russell & Christophe Deloire, Tara Susman-Pena, Kent Harrington, Kelly Born and FPU director, Leon Willems (his column was published in over 31 publications in 27 countries). 2018: Q1 During January-March 9 columns were published by Bajinder Pal Singh, Alexandra Borchardt (2), Raphaël Hadas-Lebel, George Soros, Courtney C. Radsch, Marius Dragomir, Shashi Tharoor and Robert Skidelsky. Each column is tracked for publication and measured for audience engagement and further impacts. Increased efforts are made to place editorials in media outlets within Strategic Partnership target countries. During April-June six columns were published by Anya Schiffrin, Leon Willems, Nanjala Nyabola, Gulnoza Said, Christophe Deloire and Teldah Mawarire. In Accra on May 2-3, EJC/Project Syndicate had a joint panel at UNESCO’s World Press Freedom Day celebration. The panel was an opportunity to explore the myriad challenges the media faces today in a new and unique way. We did this by organising a panel that was quite different: we invited speakers from outside of media/press freedom advocacy circles, bringing together experts from other fields, such as development, economics, science, and the arts, who exemplify how press freedom intersects all segments of society. These panelists spoke to how press freedom and the free flow of information is needed for a functioning - and flourishing – society. Panellists: Nina L. Khrushcheva, Carl Manlan, Nanjala Nyabola, Dorothy Nyambi, Binyavanga Wainaina. Moderator: Mark Nelson from the Center for International Media Assistance (CIMA).
